columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the value of the missing cash flow using the concept of the different annuities.

Using this formula, we can now solve for the present value of all the cash flows that are given.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\dfrac{\$1,700}{(1+0.09)^1}\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,559.63
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of the cash flow for Year 1 is $\$1,559.63$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\dfrac{\$2,450}{(1+0.09)^3}\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,891.85
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of the cash flow for Year 3 is $\$1,891.85$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\dfrac{\$2,980}{(1+0.09)^4}\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,111.11
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of the cash flow for Year 4 is $\$2,111.11$

From this, we can solve for the present value of the missing cash flow by taking the sum of all the available cash flow and subtracting it from $\$7,500$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value for Year 2}&=\$7,500-\$1,559.63\\
&-\$1,891.85-\$2,111.11\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,937.41
\end{aligned}$$

The present value for Year 2 is $\$1,937.41$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Future value}&=\$1,937.41 \times (1+0.09)^2\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,301.84
\end{aligned}$$

The missing cash flow is $\$2,301.84$
